questions.question: The house …………………….. I live in is very spacious.
questions.description: That…in means the same as where.

questions.question: Because I was ill for six months, …………………….. lost my job.
questions.description: Use so or because in a sentence. Don’t use them both.

questions.question: Rahul lives in ………………….
questions.description: We do not normally use the with singular proper names.

questions.question: ……………………. child can learn to swim.
questions.description: Any and every can both be used to talk in general about all the members of a class or group.

questions.question: I am ………………………. happy and sad.
questions.description: Alternately means in turn.

questions.question: ………………………. I didn’t understand a word, I kept smiling.
questions.description: Even if refers to the present or future. Even though refers to the past.

questions.question: We ………………………. each other since our school days.
questions.description: We normally use the present perfect or past perfect tense with since.

questions.question: They had been close friends since Janet …………………. small.
questions.description: A past tense can be used in the since-clause depending upon the meaning.

questions.question: In my opinion, too ………………………… mathematics is taught in schools.
questions.description: The words mathematics, physics and politics are singular countable and have no plural forms. Hence we use much with them.

questions.question: Politics ………………………… a dirty game.
questions.description: Politics is normally used as a singular uncountable noun.

questions.question: The unemployment statistics …………………………. disturbing.
questions.description: While statistics is usually singular, it does have a plural use.

questions.question: Cattle …………………………… dying due to drought.
questions.description: Cattle is a plural word and hence it takes a plural verb.

questions.question: They have a house on the ………………………… of the city.
questions.description: Outskirts is usually plural and has no singular form.

questions.question: They are raising ………………………….. for disadvantaged children.
questions.description: Funds means money.

questions.question: My …………………………. too tight.
questions.description: The noun trousers is always used in the singular form.

questions.question: If I were in that situation, I would scream until somebody …………………………. to help me.
questions.description: Would and should are mainly used in main clauses. To express the same idea we use a past tense in the subordinate clauses.

questions.question: A couple of my friends ……………………………. visiting us today.
questions.description: Plural verbs are used after expressions like a couple of + plural noun.

questions.question: Half of his students …………………………. understand his theories.
questions.description: We use a plural verb after half of.

questions.question: The actor’s individuality …………………….. him interesting.
questions.description: We use the simple present tense to talk about facts.

questions.question: Both men were ………………………. inebriated to drive.
The man was so inert …………………… he seemed dead.
questions.description: Note the pattern so ..that.

questions.question: Blame your inertia ……………………….. the hot weather.
The crew felt unsafe …………………….. an inexperienced pilot.
questions.description: We use the preposition with after safe and unsafe.

questions.question: Many men were infatuated ………………………. the beautiful young widow.
questions.description: We use the preposition with after infatuate.

questions.question: Brass is inferior ………………………. gold.
questions.description: We use the preposition to after inferior and superior.

questions.question: The police must inform the prisoner ………………………….. his legal rights.
questions.description: We use the preposition of after inform.

questions.question: Information ……………………. witchcraft can be found at the library.
Children are more …………………………. than adults.
questions.description: Ingenuous means frank, open and naive.

questions.question: Smart phones are ……………………… devices.
questions.description: Ingenious means clever or imaginative.

questions.question: Mozart had an innate genius ……………………… music.
In some of the villages they still ............................ electricity.
questions.description: We do not use the word miss to say that somebody hasn’t got something.

questions.question: She threw a glass at me, but .................................
questions.description: Lost is not used with this meaning. To miss is to fail to contact somebody.

questions.question: If we don’t hurry we will ................................ the train.
questions.description: Lost is not used with this meaning. To miss is to fail to contact somebody.

questions.question: When did you realize that the bag was ....................................?
The kitchen ought to .................................... these days.
questions.description: Somebody has to paint the kitchen. So we use a passive infinitive here.

questions.question: ................................ university students have to borrow money these days.
questions.description: We use ‘more’ before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: You ................................ be Anna’s sister – you look just like her.
questions.description: We can use must to express the conclusion that something is certain.

questions.question: Do we need .............................. seats on the train?
questions.description: When need is used as an ordinary verb, it is followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: You seldom work on Saturdays, .................................?
questions.description: We use an affirmative tag after negative expressions like seldom, hardly or rarely.

questions.question: ................................... quick results when you learn a foreign language.
questions.description: We make negative imperatives with do not + infinitive.

questions.question: There is little point in asking him, ..............................?
questions.description: Clauses with little and few are followed by affirmative question tags.

questions.question: He has few reasons to quit, ...............................?
questions.description: Clauses with little and few are followed by affirmative question tags.

questions.question: .................................... like hamburgers.
questions.description: All + noun cannot be the subject of a negative verb. Instead we write ‘not all + noun + affirmative verb’.

questions.question: I have been round ............................ looking for my puppy.
questions.description: The expression ‘all the village’ means every part of the village.

questions.question: Susie spent .................................. at home.
questions.description: The article should go before whole.

questions.question: I spent ................................ at home.
questions.description: The article goes after all.

questions.question: My dog understands every word I say – he is ............................ human.
questions.description: Almost can mean ‘similar to but not exactly the same’. Nearly is not used with this meaning.

questions.question: I ............................ wish I had accepted the invite.
questions.description: Almost can mean ‘similar to but not exactly the same’. Nearly is not used with this meaning.

questions.question: .............................. nobody came.
questions.description: Nearly cannot be used before negative words.

questions.question: I have just read ............................. Brothers Karamazov.
questions.description: Before proper nouns all of and the whole of are both possible.

questions.question: Students are not ................................. to park here.
questions.description: The verbs allowed and permitted can both be used in passive structures.

questions.question: I wasn’t .............................. to enter the club.
questions.description: Let is not used in the passive.

questions.question: ‘She is kind.’ ‘Her sister is .............................’
questions.description: We do not normally use also in short answers.

questions.question: Please give me some rice ............................
questions.description: Also is not normally used in imperatives.

questions.question: Suddenly I ……………………….. a thud.
questions.description: We hear sounds that come to our ears. To listen to something is to pay attention to it.

questions.question: I didn’t ………………………… the knock because  ………………………….. the radio.
questions.description: We hear sounds that come to our ears. To listen to something is to pay attention to it.

questions.question: Please speak a bit louder. I cannot ………………………. you.
questions.description: We hear sounds that come to our ears. To listen to something is to pay attention to it.

questions.question: I …………………………. somebody coming up the stairs.
questions.description: Hear is not normally used in the continuous form.

questions.question: ……………………………. what I am going to say.
questions.description: If there is an object, listen is used with to.

questions.question: I heard him …………………………. at the watchman.
questions.description: Hear can be followed by an object + infinitive without to or object + ing form.

questions.question: I saw her ………………………….. into the pond.
questions.description: The verb see can be followed by an object + infinitive or an object + ing form. The infinitive is used without to.

questions.question: I heard the bomb ………………………….
questions.description: The ing form here suggests that we hear an action in progress whereas the infinitive suggests that we hear the whole of the action. When it comes to the sounds of explosions we are going to hear the whole of it and hence the infinitive is used here.

questions.question: I watched the kids …………………………… in the pond.
questions.description: The ing form here suggests that we hear an action in progress whereas the infinitive suggests that we hear the whole of the action.

questions.question: I could see him ……………………………. on the bus.
questions.description: After can see or can hear only the –ing form is possible.

questions.question: I heard my name ……………………………… several times.
questions.description: My name didn’t repeat. It was repeated. We use the past participle here to suggest this idea.

questions.question: Look at them …………………………..!
questions.description: Look at can be followed by an infinitive or ing form.

questions.question: If you had practiced every day, you …………………………
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If I had …………………………. I could buy a car.
questions.description: When enough is used as an adjective it goes before the noun it modifies.

questions.question: He was …………………………… to lend me 100 dollars.
questions.description: When enough is used as an adverb, it goes after the adjective or adverb modified by it.

questions.question: Don’t come tomorrow. I would rather you ………………………….. on Sunday.
questions.description: After would rather we use a past tense with a present or future meaning.

questions.question: Nothing happened, …………………………..?
questions.description: In question tags, we use it to refer to nothing.

questions.question: …………………………… the film, I don’t want to read the book.
questions.description:
When we separate the clauses we get: I have seen the film. I don’t want to read the book.
We can combine them using having seen.

questions.question: Everything is all right, …………………………?
questions.description: In question tags we use it to refer to everything.

questions.question: You had better …………………………. saying thank-you for things.
questions.description: We use infinitive without to after ‘had better’.

questions.question: When we were kids, my uncle ……………………………. us out on his bike all round the countryside.
questions.description: Would and used to can both be used to talk about habitual behaviour in the past.

questions.question: You were foolish to try climbing up there. You ……………………………. yourself.
questions.description: Could have + past participle can be used to say that something was possible but did not happen.

questions.question: I am not accustomed to ………………………… personal information to strangers.
questions.description: After accustomed to we can use an -ing from or an infinitive without much difference of meaning.

questions.question: I slowly began ……………………………. what she was going through.
questions.description: The stative verb understand is usually used in the infinitive form.

questions.question: The higher you climb ...............................................
questions.description: In this structure with two comparative expressions, we use the same pattern in both clauses.

questions.question: The more he reads, the ............................................. he understands.
questions.description: Less is the comparative form of little. Lesser means smaller.

questions.question: The government should pay attention to the problems of .....................................................
questions.description: The unemployed means all unemployed people. The article 'the' is required in this expression.

questions.question: They saw the criminal ....................................................... open the door.
questions.description: The infinitive is used without to after the verb see.

questions.question: The strike ........................................................ if the workers' demands had been granted.
questions.description: A passive verb is required here. In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If you ........................................... more carefully, you wouldn't make so many mistakes.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: I consider ............................................... to have this opportunity of welcoming you.
The leader said that it would be unwise .............................................. the democratic demands of the people.
questions.description: Negative forms are usually made by putting not before the infinitive.

questions.question: He said that the climate ................................................. his health.
questions.description: A past tense in the main clause is almost always followed by a past tense in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: As soon as the clients .................................................., he locked up his office and went home.
questions.description: A past tense in the main clause is almost always followed by a past tense in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: The leaning tower of Pisa ...................................................... more and more every year.
questions.description: We use the present perfect continuous to talk about an action or situation that started in the past and has continued up to the present.

questions.question: He brushed ............................................. all the plans that I had carefully formulated.
questions.description: To brush something aside is to dismiss it.

questions.question: The meeting will start at six o’clock ……………………..
questions.description: As an adverb sharp can mean punctually.

questions.question: You shouldn’t have spoken to her rather ……………………….
questions.description: Sharp can mean punctually as an adverb. Sharply is used to express other meanings.

questions.question: Under no circumstances ………………………. allowed in the pub.
questions.description: After negative adverbial expressions like ‘under no circumstances’ we use an inverted word order. That means the auxiliary goes before the subject.

questions.question: He launched his own business after ………………………. from the US.
questions.description: After + ing often has the same meaning as after + having + past participle.

questions.question: She is ……………………… as her husband.
questions.description: No preposition is used in the structure ‘be + … age’.

questions.question: She ……………………….. a few minutes ago.
questions.description: We cannot normally use the present perfect tense with ago.

questions.question: ……………………….. was there.
questions.description: Hardly anybody means the same as almost nobody. Nearly is not normally used before negative expressions.

questions.question: They were quarreling all ………………………… the journey.
questions.description: We prefer through to talk about periods or activities.

questions.question: You could go by train, or ……………………….. you could hire a taxi.
questions.description: Alternatively means instead.

questions.question: We have been living ……………………… this street for ten years.
questions.description: On is used in American English and in is used in British English.

questions.question: You look ……………………. with a beard.
questions.description: Look is a copular verb. We use an adjective, not an adverb to modify copular verbs.

questions.question: Why don’t you do something for ………………………….?
questions.description: Others can mean other people.

questions.question: I am thinking of changing ……………………
questions.description: When we talk about changing one thing for another, we often use change with a plural object.

questions.question: I don’t …………………….. whether I lose – I am happy with what I have achieved.
questions.description: Care is used without about before a conjunction.

questions.question: I don’t ………………………… the result.
questions.description: Before an object, we use care about.

questions.question: I don’t take more than 5 minutes to ………………………… ready.
questions.description: We do not use become to talk about deliberate actions.

questions.question: The village ……………………….. I live is not far from the town.
questions.description: That can be used instead of which or whom. But it cannot be used instead of when or where.

questions.question: His recovery seemed …………………………
questions.description: After copular verbs, we use adjectives, not adverbs.

questions.question: I have bought …………………………..
questions.description: Some uncountable nouns are plural and do not have singular forms. Groceries is an example.

questions.question: The new job is not much different ………………………… the old one.
questions.description: From is generally used after different. In British English, to is also possible and in American English than is common.

questions.question: I doubt ……………………….. she will come this evening.
questions.description: We can use if, whether or that to introduce the clauses after the verb doubt.

questions.question: His success was ……………………….. his teacher.
questions.description: We can use due to after ‘be’. Owing to is not usually used like that.

questions.question: If you are not satisfied with their hospitality, you can go …………………………….
questions.description: Elsewhere means the same as somewhere else. It is slightly more formal.

questions.question: She takes ………………………. trouble over her work.
questions.description: Especial is not normally used as an adjective.

questions.question: The traveler asked the stranger if he ...................................... the way to the nearest inn.
questions.description: When the main verb is in the past tense, we will most probably need a past tense in the subordinate clause. The past perfect is not possible here because we are not talking about the 'earlier past'.

questions.question: The dentist suggested ....................................... my toothpaste.
questions.description: Suggest is one of those verbs that cannot be followed by a to-infinitive. It can be followed by an -ing form or a that-clause.

questions.question: The terrorist's attempt to ............................................. the bridge was foiled by the police.
questions.description: Blow up' means 'to destroy someone or something by explosion'.

questions.question: In his budget speech, the Finance Minister ................................. many bold reforms.
questions.description: 'Bring forward' means 'to introduce someone or something'.

questions.question: The suspects are still ....................................
questions.description: 'At large' means 'free uncaptured (usually said of criminals not in custody)'.

questions.question: The dilapidated building was not .....................................
questions.description: We need an adjective (habitable) here the other two options are nouns.

questions.question: ....................................... of the three boys attended the class.
questions.description: Either and neither are used to speak of two people or things.

questions.question: There were .................................. than twenty people present.
questions.description: Less is used with uncountable nouns and fewer is used with countable nouns.

questions.question: Mumbai is ................................... of India.
questions.description: Articles are used with proper nouns used as epithets.

questions.question: There are no secrets between you and .................................
questions.description: Between is a preposition. A pronoun following a preposition should be in its object form.

questions.question: .................................. buses are supposed to depart at a certain hour, they are often late.
questions.description: Although is a conjunction we need a conjunction to connect two clauses.

questions.question: Have you received any .................................. so far?
questions.description: Information is uncountable and as such it does not have a plural form.

questions.question: The man .................................... I owed money demanded immediate payment.
questions.description: The man demanded immediate payment. I owed money to him. When we connect these two clauses, the relative pronoun whom replaces the pronoun him. The preposition 'to' is retained.

questions.question: The four brothers are always ready to go to .................................. help.
questions.description: Each other is used when referring to two people and one another is used when referring to more than two people.

questions.question: This is the woman ........................................... son was abducted.
questions.description: This is the woman. Her son was abducted. The relative pronoun 'whose' replaces possessive pronouns like her, his and their.

questions.question: The flight ...................................... at
questions.description: We use the present simple to talk about future events that are part of a time table.

questions.question: When I was young, I .................................. cricket every day.
questions.description: To talk about past habits, we can use would + infinitive. The past simple is also possible here.

questions.question: .................................... it possible, I would visit London
questions.description: Were it possible means the same as if it were possible.

questions.question: ....................................... it prove to be true, I shall resign from the committee.
questions.description: 'Should it prove to be true' means the same as 'If it proves to be true'.

questions.question: ......................................... many faults, he was a good man at heart.
questions.description: In spite of and despite mean the same. The expression 'despite having' is also possible here.

questions.question: Were you ...................................... to trust him?
questions.description: As an adverb enough goes after the adjective it modifies, so foolish enough is the correct option. Infinitive structures are not used after so.

questions.question: The faster you run, ............................................... yourself.
questions.description: The same structure 'the + comparative + subject + verb' is used in both clauses.

questions.question: If you played games regularly, you ...................................... get so fat.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: She ...................................... cooking when the guests arrived.
questions.description: The past perfect is used to talk about the earlier of two past actions.

questions.question: That is not ………………… the color I wanted.
questions.description: Not quite can mean not exactly.

questions.question: You eat ……………… too much.
questions.description: Rather can modify comparatives and too.

questions.question: My mother would rather we …………….. to each other any more.
questions.description: After would rather, we use a past tense with a present or future meaning.

questions.question: I will go and see the Prime Minister himself if I have to.
questions.description: When words like himself, herself and themselves are used to mean ‘that person and nobody else’, it is used as an emphatic pronoun.
answers: Here himself is used as an emphatic pronoun.
Here himself is used as a reflexive pronoun.

questions.question: I will never forget the day ……………… my daughter was born.
questions.description: When can mean on which.

questions.question: This is Ms. Malini ………………. last year.
questions.description: The relative pronoun acts as the subject or object of the relative clause. It replaces words like he, him, her etc.

questions.question: ……………… money he has comes from his wife’s family.
questions.description: The sentence ‘What money he has…’ means the same as ‘The money that he has…’

questions.question: They saved hundreds of refugees, ………………… had been at sea for several days.
He turned the radio down ...................... he wouldn’t disturb the old lady downstairs.
questions.description: So that suggests a cause and effect relationship.

questions.question: A lot of social problems ……………. caused by unemployment.
questions.description: If the noun following ‘a lot of’ is plural, the verb is also plural.

questions.question: I will lend it to you on condition that you ……………… it back tomorrow.
questions.description: In subordinate clauses we often use the present tense to refer to the future

questions.question: It doesn’t matter what you .................... with your time or money.
questions.description: Present tenses are common after expressions like it doesn’t matter and I don’t care.

questions.question: Please describe ……………….
questions.description: We do not normally use describe with the structure indirect object + direct object.

questions.question: I would like you to explain …………………..
questions.description: We do not normally use explain with the structure indirect object + direct object.

questions.question: Can you suggest ………………..?
questions.description: We do not normally use suggest with the structure indirect object + direct object.

questions.question: I want you ……………….. my mentor.
questions.description: Before a noun complement ‘to be’ or ‘as’ is used.

questions.question: We will have to wait ………………..
questions.description: That-clauses cannot be used after wait.

questions.question: You can’t make a …………….. pass in rugby.
questions.description: Forward is the adjective. Forwards is an adverb.

questions.question: I look ………………. to hearing from you.
questions.description: In figurative expressions, the form without –s is always used.

questions.question: Do you want ………………. get you something to drink?
questions.description: That-clauses are not normally used after want.

questions.question: We drove …………………
questions.description: Homeward and homewards can both be used as adverbs.

questions.question: There is no way ……………….. that he was lying.
questions.description: After way, we can use the infinitive or ing-form with little difference of meaning.

questions.question: Summer is ……………….
questions.description: On the way can mean coming.

questions.question: …………… we go by bus or train, it will take at least 2 hours.
After he ............................ his lesson, he went out to play cricket.
questions.description: When we talk about two past events, we usually use the past perfect for the earlier of the two actions. However, we can also express this idea using the conjunctions before and after.

questions.question: While I ......................... along the street one day, I saw a dead cobra.
questions.description: When we talk about two past events, we usually use the past continuous for the longer background action.

questions.question: We left the forest and ..................... into the open plain.
As he was ........................ out of his country, he sought asylum in a foreign land.
As it was a very hot day, I ............................. in my tent.
questions.description: The simple past tense is the most common tense for talking about finished actions in the past.

questions.question: A gipsy ........................ the child while he was wandering across the meadows.
questions.description: When we talk about two past events, the simple past is used to refer to the short action that happens in the middle of the longer action.

questions.question: I once .................... a man who was walking on a rope.
As I did not know my way, I ......................... a policeman.
When I ...................... the noise, I woke up.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we need a past tense in the subordinate clause as well. We use the simple past to refer to quickly finished actions and situations.

questions.question: As he was paralytic, he ........................
questions.description: Could is the past tense form of can.

questions.question: She ..................... angry before I said a word.
His father ...................... three years ago.
questions.description: We do not use the present perfect tense with past time expressions.

questions.question: This is the first time I ................................ a concert.
questions.description: We use the present perfect tense in expressions beginning with this is the first/second/third/last etc.'

questions.question: This is ................................. gift I have ever bought.
No one has seen him .......................... January.
questions.description: We use 'since' with the starting point of something.

questions.question: She succeeded at ....................... very first attempt.
I injured ........................ while playing football yesterday.
questions.description: We use the reflexive pronoun (myself, himself, herself etc) when the subject and the object of a verb refer to the same person or thing.

questions.question: Be a responsible citizen and ......................... your taxes.
questions.description: When you pay taxes you are giving a certain amount of money to the government. When you pay for something, you are giving money in exchange for something.

questions.question: I have .............................. the drinks.
questions.description: When you pay taxes you are giving a certain amount of money to the government. When you pay for something, you are giving money in exchange for something.

questions.question: He hadn't ........................ his fee, so he could not write the exam.
questions.description: When you pay taxes you are giving a certain amount of money to the government. When you pay for something, you are giving money in exchange for something.

questions.question: Who .............................. the dinner?
questions.description: When you pay for something, you are giving money in exchange for something. For example, you can pay for the tickets, drinks or meals.

questions.question: If the rain .......................... I could take the dog out for a walk.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would / could + infinitive in the result clause.

questions.question: If I knew who did it, I .......................... his leg.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would / could + infinitive in the result clause.

questions.question: He ran as ....................... as he could.
questions.description: Quick is an adjective. Quickly is the adverb.

questions.question: He plans to start his own business in ……………….. years.
questions.description: We can say ‘a few years’ or ‘a couple of’ years.

questions.question: Yesterday, I saw the movie that my friends ………………… the week before.
questions.description: We use the past perfect for the earlier of two past actions.

questions.question: She embarked …………. a career in law graduating from a prestigious law school.
questions.description: The correct expression is ‘embark on’.

questions.question: We must guard ourselves …………… all possible infections.
We are doubtful ………………. winning the match.
The thief had been hiding in the warehouse ………………… morning.
questions.description: We use ‘since’ with the starting point. It is common after perfect tenses.

questions.question: Cars allow you to reach any place you want. ………………, they pose parking problems in cities.
questions.description: We use ‘however’ to suggest that what we are going to say contradicts what we have already said.

questions.question: John, as well as his cousins, …………… joining us.
questions.description: When we connect two subjects with ‘as well as’, the verb is likely to be singular if the first verb is singular.

questions.question: You had better hire a taxi. ……………… you will arrive late.
Tom ……………… ill last week.
questions.description:
The simple past is the normal tense for talking about finished actions in the past. 
The present perfect cannot be used with expressions that refer to a completely finished period of time.

questions.question: A grandparent’s job is easier than ………………..
questions.description: Either 'a parent's' or 'that of a parent' is possible here.

questions.question: It is important ………………….
questions.description: We put ‘not’ before infinitives and –ing forms.

questions.question: I would be surprised if he ........................
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If I had known, I ......................... you straightaway.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: Rarely ................................ such a good film.
questions.description: When the sentence begins with expressions like rarely, hardly or only, the auxiliary verb goes before the subject.

questions.question: My father often ........................ a nap in the afternoon.
questions.description: We use the simple present tense to talk about facts, routines and habits.

questions.question: If you don't want to go, you ...........................
questions.description: We use 'need not' to show the lack of obligation.

questions.question: You don't need ........................... on Saturdays.
questions.description: When need is used as an ordinary verb, it is followed by an infinitive with to.

questions.question: You ..................................... on Saturdays.
questions.description: When need is used as a modal auxiliary, it is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: If I ............................. you, I would accept this offer.
questions.description: Both 'was' and 'were' are possible here however, 'were' is preferred.

questions.description: We use 'had better' to give strong advice.

questions.question: She .............................. that she would come.
questions.description: After 'tell' we use a personal object.

questions.question: I sent ....................... a letter yesterday.
questions.description: 'Sent' is one of those verbs that can be followed by two objects - a direct object and an indirect object. When the indirect object goes first, there is no preposition.

questions.question: I sent flowers ..........................
questions.description: 'Sent' is one of those verbs that can be followed by two objects - a direct object and an indirect object. When the direct object goes first, we use the preposition 'to' or 'for' before the indirect object.

questions.question: As there was no ............................ in waiting, we left.

questions.question: ........................ all I know, she is still married to him.

questions.question: You will have to take the stairs because the lift is ...........................
questions.description: When things are out of door, they don't work.

questions.question: You ............................ better pay the fee today to avoid late payment charges.
questions.description: The correct expression is 'had better'. It is used to give strong advice.

questions.question: His electricity was ........................... off because he hadn't paid the bill.
questions.description: To cut off is to stop the supply of something.

questions.question: She ............................. tears when I told her that she had failed her exam.
questions.description: To burst into tears is to start crying.

questions.question: The plane departed on time .............................. the fog.
questions.description: In spite of is the correct expression. Despite and in spite of mean the same and are both possible here. Even though is a conjunction and should be followed by a clause.

questions.question: The chimneys ........................ too much smoke.
questions.description: To give off is to send out.

questions.question: If he …………………, we will be shocked.
questions.description: When the verb in the if clause is in the simple present tense, we use will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If I had known, I ………………. you straightaway.
..................... seen such a mess.
questions.description: When the sentence begins with a negative expression, the auxiliary verb goes before the subject.

questions.question: I ..................... tea in the morning.
questions.description: The adverb goes before the main verb.

questions.question: Would you mind my ………………… the window?

questions.question: If you don’t want to go, you ………………..

questions.description: When need is used as a modal auxiliary, it is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: If you asked more politely, I ............................ you some money.
questions.description: When the verb in the if-clause is in the simple past tense, we use would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: I would rather you ………………. home now.
questions.description: After would rather, we use a past tense to refer to the present.
